security_audit.summary: This is a prompt wrapper skill for a legitimate ONVIF security auditing tool. The skill itself contains only documentation and instructions for using the external onvifscan binary. The tool provides authentication testing and credential brute-forcing capabilities designed for authorized security assessments of IP cameras and ONVIF devices. Built-in safeguards include rate limiting and warnings about potentially destructive endpoints.

low_findings.title: Credential brute-forcing functionality
low_findings.description: The skill enables users to perform credential brute-forcing attacks against ONVIF devices using wordlists. While designed for authorized security testing, this capability could potentially be misused for unauthorized access. The tool includes rate limiting (max 20 attempts by default) as a safeguard. Quote from SKILL.md line 47-55: "Attempts credential brute-forcing on protected endpoints" with options for custom wordlists.

content.user_title: Scan ONVIF devices for security vulnerabilities
content.value_statement: Assessing the security of IP cameras and ONVIF-enabled devices is critical for protecting surveillance infrastructure. This skill provides structured access to authentication testing and credential brute-forcing tools for authorized security assessments.
actual_capabilities: Test ONVIF endpoints for unauthenticated access
Perform credential brute-forcing with customizable wordlists
Scan IP cameras and ONVIF-enabled IoT devices
Support verbose and quiet output formats
Rate-limited brute-forcing to prevent device overload
limitations: Requires onvifscan binary installed in system path
Built-in wordlists may be limited for comprehensive testing
Cannot test devices without network connectivity

use_cases.title: Assess ONVIF device security
use_cases.description: Evaluate authentication mechanisms and discover vulnerabilities in IP camera firmware and configurations.

use_cases.title: Audit internal surveillance systems
use_cases.description: Verify that organizational IP cameras meet security standards and have proper access controls configured.

use_cases.title: Test IoT device vulnerabilities
use_cases.description: Include ONVIF device assessment in red team engagements to identify weak credentials and misconfigurations.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Auth Scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Run an authentication scan on the ONVIF device at http://192.168.1.100 using onvifscan auth

prompt_templates.title: Verbose Security Check
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform a verbose ONVIF security scan with full XML output on device 192.168.1.50

prompt_templates.title: Brute Force Test
prompt_templates.prompt: Attempt credential brute-forcing on the ONVIF device using the built-in wordlists

prompt_templates.title: Custom Wordlist Scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Run brute force against the target device using custom wordlists located at /path/to/usernames.txt and /path/to/passwords.txt

output_examples.input: Scan the ONVIF device at 192.168.1.100 for security issues
output: Recommendation: Enable authentication on all endpoints

best_practices: Always obtain written authorization before scanning any device or network
Use the auth scan mode first to understand device security posture
Review rate limits and avoid excessive brute-forcing attempts
Document all findings for security assessment reports
anti_patterns: Running brute-forcing scans without explicit authorization
Testing production devices during business hours without coordination
Ignoring the warning about the -a flag testing destructive endpoints
Using default wordlists without considering device-specific constraints

faq.question: What ONVIF devices are supported?
faq.answer: Any device implementing the ONVIF protocol including IP cameras, NVRs, and video encoders from manufacturers like Axis, Hikvision, Dahua, and Bosch.

faq.question: What are the rate limits for brute-forcing?
faq.answer: The tool limits brute-forcing to 20 attempts by default to prevent device overload and network congestion.

faq.question: How do I integrate this with my security workflow?
faq.answer: Use the JSON output format for machine parsing, combine with other tools for comprehensive vulnerability assessments, and export findings to your reporting system.

faq.question: Is my scan data stored or transmitted?
faq.answer: The skill is a local prompt wrapper. All scan data remains on your system. The onvifscan binary operates locally against target devices.

faq.question: The scan failed with a connection error. What should I check?
faq.answer: Verify the device is reachable on the network, confirm ONVIF service is running on the expected port, and check that firewalls allow traffic to the device.

faq.question: How does this compare to other ONVIF testing tools?
faq.answer: This skill provides AI-assisted guidance for the onvifscan tool. For manual testing, tools like Onvif-py and Metasploit ONVIF modules offer similar capabilities.
